The Residential Sector (Veda Online)

The Residential Sector (Veda Online)#

11.1 Modelling Structure#

Table 11.1: Modelling Structure and Disaggregation for the Residential Sector in SATIM

Parameter

Disaggregation Level

Drivers

Households

Low, Middle, and High-income groups

- Population Growth: Influences the total number of households.
- Household Size: Variations in the number of people per household affect total energy consumption.
- GDP: Economic growth impacts household income, driving energy demand and appliance ownership.

Energy Service Demands

Lighting, cooking, water heating, space heating and cooling, refrigeration, other appliances

- Household Income: Determines the ability of households to afford modern energy services and appliances.
- Electrification: Access to electricity allows for a transition from traditional fuels (e.g., wood, paraffin) to modern fuels (e.g., electricity, gas).
- Policies & Regulations: Government regulations such as building energy codes, minimum energy performance standards (MEPS), and appliance standards influence energy efficiency and consumption.
- Behavioral Changes: Shifts in consumer behavior, such as energy conservation or the adoption of efficient technologies (e.g., LED lighting), affect energy demand patterns.

Fuels and Appliances

Wood, coal, paraffin, gas, electricity (appliances like televisions, washing machines, dishwashers, etc.)

- Household Income: Higher incomes enable the purchase of modern appliances and the transition to cleaner fuels.
- Electrification: As electrification expands, households shift from traditional fuels (biomass, paraffin) to electricity-based appliances.
- Policies & Subsidies: Government initiatives such as fuel subsidies and appliance standards encourage the use of more efficient technologies and cleaner energy sources.
- Appliance Standards: The enforcement of standards like MEPS drives the adoption of energy-efficient appliances, reducing energy consumption per household.

11.2 Navigating the Residential Sector with Veda Online#

In Veda Online, filtering by the following attributes in the Browse or Items View tabs will display the data for the attributes and respective years.

Table 11.2: Attributes used in the Residential Sector

Attribute

Description

Purpose in Model

Unit

TechName

Name of the technology or appliance (e.g., Electric Heater).

Identifies the technology being modeled.

N/A

Comm-IN

Incoming commodities or inputs to the technology.

Represents the resources entering the technology.

N/A

Comm-OUT

Outgoing commodities or outputs from the technology.

Represents the products generated by the technology.

N/A

EFF~(year)

Efficiency of the technology or activity in converting energy.

Indicates how effectively the technology utilizes energy, for a given year.

Percentage (%)

STOCK

Stock of the technology available in the residential sector.

Reflects the total amount of existing installed capacity of the technology.

Petajoule-annum (PJa)

INVCOST

Investment cost associated with the technology.

Represents the capital investment required for the technology.

2005 mill. R/PJ-a

NCAP_BND~0

Capacity bound at the initial period (year 0).

Sets the initial capacity limits for the technology.

kW or MW

FLO_MARK (UP)

Upper bound on the flow of energy between processes or from a process to a market.

Sets an upper constraint on how much energy (or material) can flow from a technology (e.g., solar heater) to a market.

Percentage (%)

FLO_MARK (LO)

Lower bound on the flow of energy between processes or from a process to a market.

Sets a minimum requirement for how much energy must flow to a market from a given technology (e.g., electric heaters).

Percentage (%)

11.3 Commodities in the Residential Sector#

In Veda Online, filtering by the following commodities in the Browse or Items View tabs will display relevant data for each commodity by year. All residential commodities are coded with the prefix RES. To view them, simply enter “RES*” in the commodity search bar.

Table 11.3.1: Input Commodities: Fuel Types

Commodity Code

Fuel Type

Unit

Purpose in Model

RESELC

Electricity

PJ

Represents household electricity use for lighting, heating, cooking, and appliances.

RESOKE

Oil/Paraffin

PJ

Tracks kerosene use for cooking and heating in households.

RESBIW

Biomass/Wood

PJ

Represents biomass use for residential cooking and heating, mainly in rural or low-income households.

RESCOA

Coal

PJ

Tracks coal use for cooking and heating, often in low-income households.

RESOLP

Oil/LPG

PJ

Represents LPG consumption for cooking and heating in households.

RESGAS

Natural Gas

PJ

Tracks gas consumption for heating, cooking, and water heating in households.

Filtering by the following commodities in the Browse or Items View tabs will display the relevant data for each commodity across the specified years. All residential output commodities are coded with an initial R. To view all residential commodities, use “R*” in the commodity search bar. For commodities disaggregated by income level, search using “RH*”, “RM*”, or “RL*” to display data for high-, middle-, and low-income households, respectively.

Table 11.3.2: Output Commodities: End Uses

Commodity Code

Income Level

Electrification

End Use

Unit

Purpose in Model

RHEH

High

Electrified

Space Heating

PJ

Tracks electricity use for heating in high-income homes, often with advanced heating systems.

RHEK

High

Electrified

Cooking (Kerosene)

PJ

Represents kerosene used in high-income households for backup or alternative cooking.

RHEL

High

Electrified

Lighting

PJ

Tracks electricity consumption for lighting in high-income homes.

RHEO

High

Electrified

Other

PJ

Tracks non-specific electricity use (e.g., entertainment, gadgets) in high-income households.

RHER

High

Electrified

Refrigeration

PJ

Tracks electricity use for refrigeration, which is common in high-income households.

RHEW

High

Electrified

Water Heating

PJ

Represents energy used for heating water in high-income households, including solar or electric geysers.

RHEWG

High

Electrified

Water Heating (Geyser)

PJ

Tracks electricity use specifically for electric geysers in high-income households.

RLEH

Low

Electrified

Space Heating

PJ

Tracks electricity use for heating in low-income households, often using less efficient systems.

RLEK

Low

Electrified

Cooking (Kerosene)

PJ

Tracks kerosene consumption for cooking in low-income households.

RLEL

Low

Electrified

Lighting

PJ

Tracks electricity consumption for lighting in low-income electrified households.

RLEO

Low

Electrified

Other

PJ

Tracks non-specific electricity use in low-income households.

RLER

Low

Electrified

Refrigeration

PJ

Represents electricity use for refrigeration in low-income electrified households.

RLEW

Low

Electrified

Water Heating

PJ

Tracks energy use for water heating in low-income households, often using electric or solar heaters.

RLEWG

Low

Electrified

Water Heating (Geyser)

PJ

Tracks geyser electricity consumption in low-income households.

RLNL

Low

Non-Electrified

Lighting

PJ

Represents kerosene or other non-electric lighting in low-income non-electrified households.

RMEH

Middle

Electrified

Space Heating

PJ

Tracks electricity consumption for space heating in middle-income electrified households.

RMEK

Middle

Electrified

Cooking (Kerosene)

PJ

Represents kerosene use for cooking in middle-income households.

RMEL

Middle

Electrified

Lighting

PJ

Tracks electricity consumption for lighting in middle-income households.

RMEO

Middle

Electrified

Other

PJ

Tracks non-specific electricity use in middle-income households.

RMER

Middle

Electrified

Refrigeration

PJ

Tracks electricity use for refrigeration in middle-income electrified households.

RMEW

Middle

Electrified

Water Heating

PJ

Represents energy used for water heating in middle-income households, often electric or solar geysers.

RMEWG

Middle

Electrified

Water Heating (Geyser)

PJ

Tracks geyser electricity use in middle-income households.

RMNL

Middle

Non-Electrified

Lighting

PJ

Tracks lighting fuel use (kerosene or battery lamps) in non-electrified middle-income households.

Residential End-Use Codes#

The table below lists end-use codes specifically for residential technologies:

Code

End-Use

RHEH

Space Heating

RMEK

Cooking

RLGT

Lighting

RWH

Water Heating

…

…

Example Technology Identifiers#

Identifier

Description

RHEH_NGS_EFF

Represents an efficient residential space heating technology using natural gas.

RCOK_OGS_STD

Refers to a standard residential cooking technology using oil gasoline.

Special Cases#

Certain exceptions to this convention exist. For instance, specific water heating technologies follow slightly modified naming rules. Details on these exceptions are provided below

11.4 Processes in the Residential Sector#

In the SATIMGE model, residential processes capture various household activities based on income level, electrification status, end-use type, and fuel. These process codes categorize household energy uses—such as cooking, space heating, and lighting—by fuel type and technology. Filtering for the following process codes in Browse or Items View will display the process-level data needed for detailed modeling. Processes are coded with prefixes (e.g., “RH” for high-income households), allowing quick sorting of specific household segments.

Table 11.4: Residential Sector Processes and descriptions

Process Code

Income Level

Electrification

End Use

Technology

Fuel

Existing/New

Unit

Purpose in Model

Existing

Data Sources#

  • Household Income Classification: Based on the 2011 Census (StatsSA, 2011).

  • Electrification: Assumed according to the National Development Plan (National Planning Commission, 2012).

  • Efficiency Improvements: Driven by the Standards and Labelling Programme and MEPS (DMRE, 2022), and National Energy Efficiency Standards (NEES), 2015.
